newsitem.title: HUNGARY: BA-GiroCredit rates Danubius long-term buy. [CORRECTED 14:30 GMT]
newsitem.headline: BA-GiroCredit rates Danubius long-term buy. [CORRECTED 14:30 GMT]

text.p: An analyst report by Bank Austria-GiroCredit Budapest said that as a result of better-than-expected first half figures, it recommended shares in Danubius Hotels as a "long-term buy".
"Based on the (first half year) results... we maintain our long-term buy recommendation on the stock," analyst Antony Vago said.
Danubius, which released its first half results two weeks ago, said it boosted its consolidated net profits to 1.30 billion forints from 839.8 million in the same period of 1995.
Vago said he had revised the net profit figure for 1996 upwards to 2,039.7 million forints.

With respect to the Danubius's widely reported bid for the Hungaria Szalloda (formerly HungarHotels) hotel chain, the report suggested that if the company won the tender and financed it using a capital increase, the earnings per share (EPS) would increase to 284.9 (corrects from 316.3) forints, whereas if the deal were financed with debt the EPS could fall to 244.3 forints.

The Budapest daily Nepszabadsag reported on Thursday that State Privatisation Agency APV had declared Danubius the winner of the privatisation tender for Hungaria Szalloda at its meeting on Wednesday.
According to Nepszabadsag, Danubius submitted the highest bid, offering more than eight billion forints for the chain which has 14 hotels.
The Budapest Stock Exchange (BSE) on Thursday suspended trading in Danubius shares on the strength of the report.
APV is expected to make an announcement on the sale later on Thursday.
